sp.p: Your apprehenſions, Harriet, are groundleſs—from what I learn of the Count's character, I believe him to be a man of too nice honour; too equitable, too generous, to reduce me to the neceſſity of proceeding to extremities; I only wiſh to explain matters to him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I can recommend a much better courſe to you, and one much more likely to ſucceed—Go to your uncle, that good, that noble-hearted man —tell him your ſtory—if any body has weight with Sir Oliver, it is Colonel Talbot.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nobody has weight with him, when avarice claims his ear.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You are miſtaken: he is not ſo great a ſlave to avarice as you ſuppoſe him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: He is your uncle, Harriet, and I cannot ſpeak of him with harſhneſs.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I know by your eyes, you are not ſo angry as you were.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I will be guided by you in every thing—There is a faſcinating power, Harriet, in your looks and accents, when you wou'd perſuade, that cannot be reſiſted; a melting ſoftneſs clings about my heart as I liſten and behold you; there is ſure a divinity in angel-beauty! You cauſed the tempeſt in my ſoul, and have calm'd it.

div.head: SCENE, An Apartment at Mandeville's.
div.stage: Caleb and Johnſon diſcovered over a Bottle.

sp.speaker: Caleb.
sp.p: COME, my boy, ſince you won't go to Jacob Wilkins's with me, we'll tope a little here—Fill your glaſs higher—higher yet; I'll have no ſkylights—This is a bumper toaſt.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: Well, what is it?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Our noble ſelves.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: I find that you think a ſentiment, like charity, ſhould begin at home.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: I do to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: We ſhould have begun with the king and conſtitution.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Then here it goes—and, though it's the ſecond toaſt now, it ſhall be firſt next bottle.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: Next bottle! But, Mr. Talbot, I have a particular engagement upon my hands this evening—I hope you'll excuſe my leaving you.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: You ſhan't ſtir a foot (Puſhes him to his chair.) Your wine's ſo good—I wonder how any body can quit ſuch liquor.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe there's a lady in the caſe—you won't preſs me to ſtay ſurely, after I tell you that?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Damn it! Take me with you!

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: Impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Then ſit down and drink with me, for I won't part with you.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: What the devil ſhall I do (Looking at his watch.) It wants but a quarter to ſix, and Mrs. Wilkins will be waiting tea for me.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Come, to the charge again, and a brimmer it ſhall be.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: (Aſide.) I ſhall get ſuddled too;—I have often in a frolic aſſumed drunkenneſs; ſuppoſe I practiſe that ſtratagem now to get away from him? (Hiccups. &c.)

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Why, now I look at you, I think you are getting a little forward.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: But I am not quite ſo bad as you think; do let me go, Mr. Talbot.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Do you think I have no more regard for you? I tell you, you muſt go to bed—now do go to bed.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: How the devil ſhall I get away from him? Zounds, Sir, I am not drunk.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Poor fellow! I am ſorry to ſee you ſo far gone; but I'll take care of you for this night. No, no; no going out this night.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: S'death and fire! Will this convince you that I am ſober.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Take another turn, and I'll tell you.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: But will you let me go then?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: After we have had another bottle.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: Zounds! another bottle!—Well, I'll go down to the cellar for it.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Mind you don't ſtay.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: No, no; I ſhan't ſtay— (Aſide.) long in this houſe, now I have got out of your clutches, young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p:
This is a deviliſh honeſt bottle—there is half a pint in it yet—Well, my friend is gone, ſo here goes his health (Drinks.) Poor fellow!—I never ſaw a man ſo ſoon drunk and ſober—Damn it, how he ſtays!—I long for a glaſs of wine; tho
he's not here, ecod, I'll fill my glaſs—a good bottle of wine is excellent company.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What, Sir, drinking by yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: I'm ſure that's not my fault—I ſhall be very glad if you'll ſit down and keep me company: I expect Johnſon every minute with the other bottle.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe. Sir, Johnſon has been your companion?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Yes; and a choice companion he is; only apt to get muzz'd too ſoon.—Come, come, let me fill you a glaſs.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I'll drink none, Sir; nor ſhall you drink any more; your father deſires to ſee you inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: You'll let me finiſh the bottle?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You muſt drink no more! He puts me beyond all patience.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Ecod, then I'll take it with me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Set it down, Sir.

div.stage: [Lays bold on him violently. Caleb, in a fright, drops and breaks the Bottle.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: There, (looking at it), I have ſet it down, and am ready to go with you; we muſt be good friends again now we have crack'd a bottle together.

div.head: SCENE, A Library.

sp.speaker: Crevelt.
sp.p:
It is to no purpoſe—I cannot read—This adorable girl has taken ſuch entire poſſeſſion of my mind, it has'nt room for any other object; when Mr. Mandeville told me ſhe was going to be married,
and to whom, my hope died within me, for then I knew all hope was loſt; but grant there was no diſhonour, no ingratitude in harbouring a paſſion for a woman intended for the ſon of my benefactor; how ſhould a low-born, abject thing, like me, aſpite to one ſo much above him? Wou'd not my birth be an inſurmountable bar to my hopes? She comes this way—I would avoid her, but have not the power.

div.stage: Enter Charlotte (with a Volume of Shakeſpeare in her Hand.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.q:
—
She never told her love;
But let concealment, like a worm i'th'bud,
Feed on her damaſk cheek: ſhe pin'd in thought,
And with a green and yellow melancholy,
She ſat like Patience on a monument,
Smiling at grief—
sp.p: Bleſs me! Captain Crevelt (ſtarting.) I did'nt ſee you—I was quite abſorbed in poor Viola's melancholy relation of undivulged love; this little picture is ſo highly finiſhed, ſo delicately coloured with touches of the true pathetic, that I never read it without being wonderfully affected—Don't you think it one of the fineſt paſſages in all Shakeſpeare?

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: I ſo much admire it, Madam, that I would give the world this moment for the pencil of its immortal writer, to paint one of our ſex in the ſame ſtate of uncomplaining deſpondency.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
I proteſt you ſpoke thoſe laſt words with ſo ſerious an air, that I'm half inclined to think you're in love yourſelf: if that be the caſe, come, make me your confidante; I'll be as ſecret and as ſilent as Shakeſpeare's own marble Grief and Patience: I have the muſic of the Avon ſwan this moment at my heart, and cou'd hear a lover whiſper his tale under a tree in which the
nightingale ſung, and the moon tipt its boughs with ſilver.

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: You ſpeak, Madam, like one well vers'd in the paſſion.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: And is that ſtrange, Sir, when I come with Shakeſpeare in my hand; a maſter who teaches the whole hiſtory of the paſſions? His keen and ardent eye in a fine frenzy rolling, pierced into the ſecret chambers of the heart where the paſſions ſlumber; and woke them, as he ſwept his lyre divine to all their changeful moods of pain and joy, till kindled up to madneſs, or to ecſtaſy; but, when he touches upon love, though the flaſh be momentary, it reſembles lightning, ſuddenly rifting the ſurface of the earth, and diſcloſing the radiant portal of a diamond quarry.

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: Were I to wiſh another laurel on the grave of Shakeſpeare, it ſhould be planted by the hand of ſo charming a commentator.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Sir, there is a laurel already planted on his grave by one of our ſex, which will flouriſh till the ſpirit of his genius, and his writings are no more remembered—but to the point—I have pronoune'd you in love; now let me know who your miſtreſs is?

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: Madam, I dare not.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Dare not! Is that a ſoldier's phraſe? Courage, man; there is nothing impoſſible to ſpirit and perſeverance: beſides, the more difficulties lay in the road to your miſtreſs, the better ſhe'll like you for ſurmounting them.

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe there was a difficulty not to be ſurmounted?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: If your miſtreſs does not diſlike you, I now of no other difficulty which is not to be ſurmounted.

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: But even preſuming that were the caſe, which I have by no means reaſon to imagine, I cannot think of her without condemning myſelf.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Is ſhe ſo much beneath you?

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: She's above my praiſe, and above my hopes.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: If ſhe deſerves all this adoration, ſhe never will think herſelf above a man of merit.

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: Then, Madam, you don't think marrying for love entirely out of faſhion?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I never would marry for any thing elſe.

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Then I'm undone; ſhe loves the man for whom ſhe is intended; and the aſſurance of that I have now received from her own lips, was meant as a reproach to a paſſion ſhe has diſcovered, in ſpite of all my efforts to conceal it.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (Seeing his diſorder) What's the matter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: I fear, Madam, I only interrupt your ſtudies.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: How can you talk ſo! I don't know any one whoſe converſation, on ſo ſhort an acquaintance, is ſo agreeable to me; this laſt has been particularly intereſting.

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: It is plain from the ſarcaſm of that reply, that ſhe underſtands me—but I am juſtly puniſhed for my apoſtacy to honour, in daring to think of her.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: He appears confuſed and embarraſſed all of a ſudden; I fear my vanity has betrayed me too far, and that I have been miſtaken in the object of his affections.

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: I have not power to ſpeak to her.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: No, no; I'm not the object.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, the Colonel wiſhes to ſee you immediately.

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: What a releaſe from torture! (Aſide.) I ſhall wait on him. (Exit Servant.) Madam, your moſt obedient.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: So, I have as good as told a man I like him, who, it is plain, is in love with another woman: unhappy Charlotte!

div.stage: Enter Sir Oliver (Speaks as he comes on.)

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Charlotte!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Sir! How melancholy a monoſyllable comes from a woman's mouth; it ſounds as diſmal as a ſingle bell after a full peal. But, Charlotte, what's the matter? I never ſaw you ſo thoughtful before: I hope it is not your marriage that makes you uneaſy.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: It never gave me an uneaſy moment. I had made up my mind on the ſubject.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Well, well; let the matter reſt then: however, I muſt confeſs I ſhould like to ſee my girl well married and ſettled before I left the world.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I don't think I ſhall ever marry.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Never marry!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Confound thoſe monoſyllables! Charlotte, let me have no more of them; the laconic ſtyle does not become you: I wonder from whom you take it; for my part I'm fond of the figure of amplification in diſcourſe; and I'm ſure your mother deals in an eloquence copious at times, even to redundancy.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Sir, I have not ſpirits for converſation.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p:
I am ſurpriſed at that, when you have every thing your own way: you won't marry this body, nor you won't marry t'other; and I, like
an eaſy, indulgent old ſoul, humour you in every thing, fond as I am of contradiction.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Hav'nt you all's one as held me up to ſale to the higheſt bidder?—I was firſt intended for Mr. Mandeville, next deſtined to Colonel Talbot's new-found heir.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: His new-found bear you ſhou'd ſay; but Charlotte, Charlotte, how uncandid you are! when I propoſed the laſt match I had not ſeen the man.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Sir, you change your mind ſo often, and band me about in ſo extraordinary a manner, that I ſhall become a topic for public ridicule.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Well, and if I do change my mind often, isn't it for your good? As one project ſtarts up in my mind better than another, in order to take advantage of that, I muſt naturally contradict myſelf. The Spaniſh proverb ſays, a wiſe man often changes his mind, a fool never.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: According to that proverb you ſhould be a ſecond Solomon: who you intend for me next I cannot poſſibly gueſs; but as I never will marry without your conſent, I truſt it will not be deemed undutiful, if I always retain a negative to myſelf, in a matter which ſo nearly concerns my happineſs as the choice of a huſband.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: I fear, like all great projectors and politicians, I reſine too much; I ſpin the wires that compoſe my nets ſo fine, that though they anſwer the purpoſe of deceiving the eye, when their ſtrength is tried, a touch breaks them.—What's to be done? ſhe actually ſets my authority at defiance; but this comes of rich uncles leaving fat legacies to their nieces; it converts a father into a cypher.

sp.speaker: Lady O.
sp.p: Sir Oliver, Sir Oliver, the whole world is condemning you.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: So much the better; a quarter of the world never was right, but the whole, is always wrong; you have brought me this good news, I ſuppoſe, knowing I was out of ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: To contract for me, without my knowledge, and with an utter ſtranger too! as if I had, not the common privilege of a thinking rational creature?

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Ecod, I think you have too much of that privilege: why, you ungrateful minx, do you fly in my face for endeavouring to get a count for you.

sp.speaker: Lady O.
sp.p: A count! A ſtrange kind of count—the fellow made love to me.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Then indeed muſt he be a ſtrange kind of count.

sp.speaker: Lady O.
sp.p: I ſhall ſue for a ſeparate maintenance.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And I ſhall ſue for the little property my father left in his hands.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Damn it, ſince you have begun, come, fire away from both ſides, volley after volley; don't ſpare me, I'll make you raiſe the ſiege at laſt; contradiction's my element, as fire is the Salamander's. I can't have too much of it; my opinion is impregnable.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: It's in vain to ſpeak to him.

sp.speaker: Lady O.
sp.p: Speak to him, child! now he's in all his glory.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Hobbs maintains that the whole world is in a ſtate of warfare, and I believe him.

sp.speaker: Lady O.
sp.p: I ſay, Sir Oliver, are you deaf?

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: But it is a wiſe law in nature.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Dear uncle, will you liſten to me?

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Oppoſition calls forth the latent powers of the mind.

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p: Was there ever any thing ſo provoking!

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Your greateſt men have been form'd by difficulties.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Every moment is big with danger to my happineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Methinks I now reſemble the memorable column of Engliſh infantry at Fontenoy, marching down between two forts, with all their batteries playing upon it: whiz, fly the ſmall ſhot from the left; and bang go the great guns from the right; but on we march, firm as a wedge; without confuſion, without diſorder, without diſmay; and quit the field of battle with honour.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My principal fear, is a quarrel between Count Pierpoint and Mr. Mandeville.

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p: You had better ſpeak to his friend, Captain Crevelt; for my part, I have no influence! with the Count.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Dear aunt, how can you talk thus? So fine a woman will never loſe her influence.

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p: Pray, Harriet, have you ever read that elegant fellow St. Everemond's account of the lovely Ninon; She who retain'd her beauty and power of faſcination to the age of eighty?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I have never read St. Everemond, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p: Then you have read nothing: he was the intimate friend of Fontaine, Racine, and Corneille; all the great men of his time valued his friendſhip: but what moſt endears him to me was his eſteem for the lovely Ninon—I ſhall never forget one of her letters, in which ſhe mentions he firſt wearing ſpectacles; but, ſaid that charming woman, as I had always a grave look, ſpectacle become me.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
I declare, aunt, I have always thought th •
ſame of you, when I have ſeen you with your ſpectacles on.

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p: But you're miſtaken, Harriet, if you ſuppoſe I wear ſpectacles from any neceſſity I have for them—I wear them by way of prevention.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: As I hope to live, here comes the Count; he'll teaze me to death if I ſtay—I never ſaw you look ſo well, aunt.

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p: You may go, Harriet, and find Captain Crevelt—I'll once more try my influence with this Frenchman.

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p: Well, Count; I hope you have chang'd your opinion ſince our laſt converſation, and that you're become a little more Angliciſed.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Eh bien! Madam, je ne puis pas comprendre, I no underſtand.

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p: Why, we have chang'd characters; you can't underſtand me now, and I cou'dn't underſtand you before: but, Count, I'd adviſe you to conſider you are in England; and tho' it may be the etiquette in France to treat a married lady with as much attention as a ſingle, it is in this country of jealous circumſpection, very dangerous: it is almoſt ſufficient to cauſe a ſeparation.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ah, Madam! have a ſome pity on thoſe whom your charms enſlave, quand I'amour eſt dans le coeur; il fait l'eſprit comme lui même; dat is, ven love is in de heart, he make a dey underſtand blind as himſelf, by Gar.

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p: The French are certainly the moſt agreeable people in the world; if they tranſgreſs, they make reparation with ſo good a grace, that it's delightful to be on good or bad terms with them.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
I made von grand faux pas; but like good general, me vill profit by my loſs. (Aſide.)—Madam
Oldſtock is vat you call von grand baſtion, or outwork: I will take a that firſt; & la petite citadel, Mademoiſelle Harriet, follow of courſe, by Gar.

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p: Well, Count, I forgive you; but it's on condition that you are more circumſpect in future.

div.stage: Enter Sir Oliver at the Back of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: If I cou'd lay my hand on Burn's Juſtice in the library, that wou'd ſet me right: but I think it's a queſtion for gentlemen of the common law.—Eh! what's all this?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam, permettez moi baiſer votte main; I muſt kiſs a your von pretty hand in ſign of reconciliation.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: I was thinking of the common law; but here promiſes to ariſe a queſtion for gentlemen of the civil law.

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p: Jealouſy, Count, is a tree of Engliſh growth.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: It may be a tree of Engliſh growth; but it's a tree would never flouriſh, if a taſte for French gardening did not ſo often make the branches ſprout.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Mon Dieu! quelle grand diſproportion in your age and the Chevalier Oldſtock!

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p: When a woman marries very young, my Lord, a dozen years difference is nothing in the age of a huſband.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: A dozen years! Damme, if there's a dozen months between us.

sp.speaker: Lady O.
sp.p: That's a moſt beautiful brilliant, Count on your finger—I think I never ſaw ſo large a one the rich cluſter of its rays caſt a light actually celeſtial.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p:
If that poor diamond cou'dſ peak now
perhaps we'd find it was not very celeſtially come by.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: To reconcile me complete, permettez moi to make you von preſent.

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p: Dear Count, I cannot think of accepting a ring of ſuch immenſe value—No, no, Count, I am not ſuch an infant as to wiſh to poſſeſs every thing that I admire.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: No, to be ſure, you an't.—Why, Count, how is all this ?

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p: Oh! heavens! Sir Oliver!

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Yes, my Lady; does the great diſproportion of our years frighten you?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Upon my vord, Monſieur Oldſtock, this is not behave with your uſual politeſſe.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Why, what the devil, man! aren't you content with one of my chickens, but you muſt have my old hen into the bargain?

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p: Old hen!

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Yes, my Lady; when I had you firſt you were no pullet.

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p: Now there will be no end to his ſuſpicions.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Ecod, I think this is putting ſuſpicion out of the queſtion,—Well, my Lady, what have you to ſay for yourſelf ? You aſk'd me if I wasn't deaf; now are you dumb?—Damn it, ſay ſomething, if it's only to contradict me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Monſieur Oldſtock, je ſuis—I am your very good friend.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: You are, Count; and, what's more, I find you're my wife's friend.

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p:
Sir Oliver, conſcious as I am of the purity of my thoughts, I cou'd look down with contempt on every extravagance to which your jealous temper hurries you; but when I conſider how the faireſt reputations are every day injur'd from the
ſlighteſt foundations—if it ſhou'd creep into the public prints—

sp.speaker: Sir. O.
sp.p: Then I'll give you a little comfort—nobody will believe it.

sp.speaker: La. O.
sp.p: The cool malignity of his temper is even more provoking than his jealouſy—I can't bear to have been all my life reproach'd for nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Count Pierpoint, no apologies: I am not at all angry with you, nor do I entertain any ſuſpicion of, my wife—Love of admiration is her ruling paſſion; and as long as ſhe lives, ſhe'll fancy herſelf an object of that admiration.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Vous ſavez trés bien my paſſion pour Mademoiſelle Harriet.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: I know every thing—I now ſee your view, in all this attention to Lady Oldſtock: you imprudently made her your enemy, not knowing her character; but you have very wiſely rectified your miſtake.—You ſee, Count, I'm a keen old fellow; I haven't liv'd for nothing ſo many years in the world.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Mon Dieu! vous etes un Machiavel.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Come along, Count.—But before you go, how do you think your friend Colonel Talbot ſtands affected as to matrimony? Do you imagine, if a fine girl was thrown in his way, that he'd marry her?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nothing more like, on my vord; il eſt un homme de gallantrie; ſans dout he has a de ſon, if dat be no objection.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Objection! he ſhou'd marry for that very reaſon, and get more ſons, if it was only to convince the world that he has mended his hand in the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I AM half in love with Count Pierpoint for his noble behaviour—The moment matters were properly explain'd to him, he withdrew his claim inſtantly—Well, I never more will hear the French ſpoken ill of; they carry the point of honour to a pitch of heroiſm—but, Charlotte, what is the matter? Your ſpirits are intolerably depreſſed!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: You only fancy ſo from the unuſual gaiety of your own.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I have a great mind to ſend Captain Crevelt to you; you are juſt fit company for each other: two moping, melancholy fools.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: From ſome converſation I have had with him, I take it that he is in love.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And I fancy I have a fair friend much in the ſame ſituation.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: He leaves town to day.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Unleſs you iſſue your ſovereign commands to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: My ſovereign commands! How you trifle: what influence have I over him?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: That influence which a beautiful woman will always have over a man of exquiſite ſenſibility—Mandeville told me he was eternally talking of you.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Talking of me! Lord, I wonder what the man can have to ſay about me!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
Oh! a thouſand handſome things, I dare
ſay: but if you wiſh to be ſatisfied as to the particulars, you may have them from the gentleman's own mouth, for here he comes; ſo I'll leave you together.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Then you will be ſo ill natured?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Good natured, ſweet couſin.—

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Eternally talking of me! Whence, then, aroſe his ſudden coldneſs and reſerve, when I but too plainly diſcovered my partiality for him? Yet I may have been miſtaken; a mind poſſeſſed of ſo much delicacy as his, might have deemed it criminal to addreſs me on the ſcore of love, at a time h • thought I was intended for the ſon of his friend Colonel Talbot—it is, it muſt be ſo—the pulſes o • my heart quicken at the thought—but he's here.

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: Miſs Oldſtock, as I mean to quit tow this evening, and poſſibly may never ſee you again I am come to ſolicit the honour of a few minute converſation.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Never ſee me again! I hope you are no going back to India.

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: No, Madam, that is not my intention.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Oh! then I underſtand you; it is th • compound of every female excellence, of who you ſpoke to me in ſuch raptures, who is the cau •• of your leaving us.

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: I own it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: But you talk'd of never ſeeing me again is your miſtreſs that jealous creature as to exa •• ſuch a promiſe from you?

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p:
No, Madam; that is a puniſhment I v •
luntarily inflict upon myſelf.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
You do ſay the moſt gallant things, wi •• the moſt ſombre countenance; your wit and yo •• face, Captain Crevelt, are the diamond and
ſoil; the dark ſhade of the one, lends a more vivid glow to the other's ſparkling brilliancy:—what an alteration the preſence of your miſtreſs wou'd make in your looks; Cou'd you look thus in her preſence?

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: In the preſent ſtate of my heart, I could hot look otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: No! not if ſhe ſmil'd upon you?

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: A ſmile from her wou'd raiſe me from deſpair: but that, Madam—Confuſion! yonder I ſee Colonel Talbot; this is the ſecond time to day he has found me in earneſt converſation with her.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I didn't think it poſſible till now, Colonel Talbot cou'd put me out of temper.

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: Will he not ſuſpect that I am meanly ſtealing myſelf upon her affections, and attribute her diſlike of his ſon to me?—But he comes; I cannot meet his eye in the preſent ſtate of my feelings.—Adieu, dear Miſs Oldſtock!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: But are we never to meet again?

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: It is a ſacrifice, Madam, that pierces, and widows my heart for ever; but honour and gratitude demand it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Wasn't that Captain Crevelt, Miſs Oldſtock, that parted from you?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; he has juſt taken his leave of me, and ſaid I ſhall never ſee him again.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: There is a reſinement in Crevelt's temper, that to ſtrangers makes his conduct at times appear very unaccountable; but I fancy I have diſcovered the cauſe of this extraordinary reſolution.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: And ſure, Sir, you can prevail upon him to alter it?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Then my lovely girl wiſhes he ſhould alter his reſolution?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! is it poſſible to be acquainted with ſo noble, ſo accompliſh'd, ſo brave a youth, and not eſteem him? Never ſee me more!—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: It is as I ſuſpected; and, indeed, as I wiſh; for who but Crevelt is worthy of ſuch a woman?— (Aſide.) I hope, Miſs Oldſtock, you are now perfectly convinced, that I wou'd not purchaſe the greateſt earthly happineſs at the price of your peace of mind—highly as my pride, and natural affection wou'd be gratified to call you daughter, I truſt I can turn my eye with manly firmneſs from the bright, the flattering proſpect; and, reſign'd to the diſpenſations of a Power who never afflicts his creature but for wiſe and good purpoſes, point out a man in every reſpect but birth and fortune deſerving of you.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Birth and fortune, Colonel! deſpicable diſtinctions! when nature aſſerts her ſuperior claims to reverence, by ennobling the ſpirit, how low it lays the inſolence of anceſtry, and humbles the vanity of wealth.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Madam, your words penetrate my very ſoul; with an aching, joyleſs heart, I look back to thoſe imaginary ſcenes of happineſs, fancy had painted in meeting with a ſon; the only pledge of love from the firſt object of my affections, and whoſe image ſtill warms this deſolated boſom—Birth! when I ſurvey my own offspring, and behold poor Crevelt, I am aſham'd to think ſo empty a thing as family pride had ever any inſluence over me.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: But you will prevail upon him to alter his reſolution?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: On one condition, Madam.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: What is that, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p:
That you will receive him as my adopted
ſon—Your father's objections I will remove, by making him your equal in fortune.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I don't know how to thank you, Colonel; but, perhaps, he's already gone.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Gone, without ſeeing me firſt, impoſſible!—But what ſays my ſweet girl to the propoſal I have made her?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: You are ſo good, ſo diſintereſted, and ſo generous, that it is impoſſible not to acquieſce in any propoſal of your's: but yet I will not make you an abſolute promiſe; mind that, Colonel; till I find you have effectually accompliſhed my requeſt, and induced Captain Crevelt to alter his reſolution.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Luckily, Sir Oliver has taken a very great liking to him; and told me that he wou'd inſiſt upon his paſſing a few days at his houſe, previous to viſiting his relations—Tho' Crevelt poſſeſſes the ſpirit of a lion, there is a gentleneſs and flexibility in his nature, which cannot reſiſt ſolicitation from a friend—Oh, my heart, be ſtill! tho' I am denied happineſs in that quarter whence I fondly expected it, let me enjoy it as Heaven thinks proper to beſtow the boon, by exerting my beſt efforts to impart it to the truly deſerving.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: J'eſpere, Monſieur Mandeville, you are perfectly ſatisfy—ſur mon honneur, had I know Mademoiſelle Harriet was engagé, I never wou'd pay l'addreſſe.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.p: I believe it, Count; and hope you will forgive the warmth, I was at firſt: betrayed into.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Mon Dieu! il eſt l'everveſcence d'un grande ame no brave man ever reſign ſa maitreſſe avec ſang froid.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p:
Now Mandeville, to completely remove
your fears in regard to Harriet, know, I have made your peace with her uncle—wou'd you believe it? he actually propoſed his daughter to me—however by the dint of argument, added to the influence of an old friendſhip, I at laſt brought him to reaſon.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Colonel, Colonel, is this ſtrict obſervance of treaty? the carriages are waiting for us at the door—were we not all to ſet off for my houſe immediately; did you not promiſe to paſs ten days with me when you had contradicted me into conſent at laſt?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Monſieur Oldſtock, your niece was very pretty to be ſure; mais, mon Dieu! votre fille be very pretty auſſi; me underſtand ſhe ville not marry young Monſieur Talbot, & mon ami the Colonel will not have her—ch bien, vat you ſay to me for von huſband.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: With all my heart and ſoul, Count—I don't know a French gentleman of a long time I have taken ſuch a liking to—damn me! if you have not a fine roaſt-beef countenance.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I fancy, Count, that lady's affections are alſo engaged.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Je ſuis trés malheureux! all de Engliſh lady be engaged! but me be not ſurprized; for if de foreigner ſet ſo much value on de Engliſh lady, vat muſt their own countrymen who know them better, do?

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Why, what the deuce, Colonel, is all this? You won't marry my daughter yourſelf; you won't ſuffer your ſon, whatever her inclinations may be, to marry her; and now you put the Count againſt her.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Will you leave the lady to her own choice?

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: The worſt of it is, I muſt do that—Count, a word in your ear—to her yourſelf—you're a dev'liſh ſtraight, well looking fellow; no appearance of frogs about you, except upon your coat—I ſhou'd like to ſee an union between France and England, if it were only becauſe it has been ſo long thought a contradiction in politics.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: How unſubſtantial are all the proſpects of man, in whatever hope flatters him with happineſs—this unhappy boy diſtracts me!

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Damn me! if I wou'dn't ſend him down into Wales or Yorkſhire—for about fifteen pounds a year, you may get him decently boarded and clad, and educated into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I have been in ſearch of Mr. Talbot, Sir, ſince you ſpoke to me; and have juſt heard that he is gone to one Jacob Wilkins's, an innkeeper, near Smithfield.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am expoſed, you ſee, already.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: It's your own fault if you continue to be expoſed; come along, Colonel; yonder I ſee Captain Crevelt putting the women into the carriages: We'll drive round by this "Wilkins's; and take this young mohawk by ſurpriſe; the moment you get poſſeſſion of him, baniſh him into Wales.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I will myſelf go in perſon to Wilkins's; and from his own lips learn every particular reſpecting this unhappy youth, from the hour I left him in his care; and as you propoſe going home that way, Sir Oliver, I will treſpaſs ſo far upon your patience as to requeſt you will wait for me, whilſt I make this inquiry.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.p: Dear Sir, don't make yourſelf ſo unhappy.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What is there wealth can purchaſe I cannot poſſeſs? my feelings are at once a ſatire, and a leſſon to avarice.

div.head: SCENE, a Room at Jacob Wilkins's.
div.stage: Johnſon and Mrs. Wilkins diſcovered at Tea.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: I'm ſure I ſhall never forget the firſt time I was in this room; where you ſee Mr. Wilkins has his Honor the Colonel's picture hung up—dear heart, what a handſome man he is! it's a great pity he does not marry.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: He's very much altered—conſider, it's many years ſince that picture was painted; his face is parched to the complexion of an old drum head, and his hair is perfectly ſilver.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: What effect ſilver hair may have upon your great ladies I will not pretend to ſay; but this I'll ſwear to; bait your hook properly with gold, and a poor girl is a trout you may take with a ſingle hair of any colour. If it wasn't for his money, do you think I'd ever have married old Jacob Wilkins?

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: Why no, I hardly think you wou'd; but why, my dear creature, has his name eſcaped your lips? ſhou'd he poſſeſs ſuch a treaſure! the man worthy of you ſhould always meet you with the ardour of a lover, and dart as I do with tranſport into your arms.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Oh! madam! madam! my matter is come home, and is raving like mad at your leaving the bar, and drinking tea up ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: He doesn't know I have any body with me?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Lord! ma'am, to be ſure he doesn't; I told him you were not well, and that you found the bar too cold for you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: You're an excellent girl.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: How the devil will you get me out?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I hear his cough at the foot of the ſtairs—dear Madam he's coming up.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: 'S'death I'll run and ſhut myſelf up in hat little room yonder.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: By no means! that's our own bed chamber; his bureau is in it; and as he pays his brewer to day, perhaps it's there he's going now or money.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I have it Madam; I'll let down this window curtain, and the gentleman may get behind it; if my maſter aſks why it is down, you may ſay you were ſo ill, the light was too much for you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: Such a ſervant is worth her weight in gold.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Here, Madam; tie this handkerchief about your head; appear very bad indeed—there, Madam, let him come now when he pleaſes, we are ready for him.

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: So, Mr. Amber; you have a curioſity to ſee the upper part of my houſe; you can't think how pleaſant it is; my wife can tell you what a proſpect there is on my upper ſtory.

sp.speaker: Amber.
sp.p: Poor Mrs. Wilkins is quite muffled up; he's very bad poor woman; I'm ſorry we diſturbed her.

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: Why, Fanny, my love, what's the mater? you were very well when I went out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: I have been ſeized all of a ſudden, with ſuch a terrible pain in one ſide of my face I can hardly get my words out.

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: I am ſorry to hear this, Fanny—but what wiſeacre has let this, curtain down? I can't bear to ſhut out the light of a fine day.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: Has the brute a mind to be the death of me?

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: Will it do you any good to keep me in the dark?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: To be ſure it will when I can't bear the light.

sp.speaker: Amber.
sp.p: Friend Wilkins, friend Wilkins, the light is too much for her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: You're a conſiderate man, Mr, Amber, and I dare ſay make an excellent huſband.

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: Well, well, then let the curtain remain down—come, Fanny, give your old Jacob a kiſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: I'm too fond of you, Jacob, and you take advantage of that.

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: No, but I don't—kiſs me again, you fond fool, it will do you good.

sp.speaker: Amber.
sp.p: Ah! you're a happy couple; but you take the right method to be ſo, by giving way to one another.

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: But now we are up ſtairs, friend Amber ſit down, and I'll go bring ſome money out of the next room and pay you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: I beg of you, Jacob, to take him down ſtairs and pay him; even your talking ſets my head diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: My dear, I ſhan't be two minutes ſettling with him; it will affront him if you turn him out of the room; you ſhall have the place to yourſel • immediately.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Madam, you're undone; if you don't come down ſtairs immediately; Ned, the new waiter, ſaw Mr. Johnſon, and He as good as told me he'd acquaint my maſter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: What ſhall I do? I'm afraid to leave the room.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: You need'nt ſtop a minute; it's only ſqueezing Ned's hand, and ſlipping a ſly half guinea into it, and all will be right.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: Oh! Betty, I wiſh he was well out of the houſe—you'll excuſe me, Mr. Amber, a little; I'm wanted down ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Don't notice me, child, buſineſs muſt be minded; but let me ſee; ſuppoſe I ſign my receipt and have it ready for him.

div.stage: [Taking out his pocket book and inkhorn.

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: Here is the money, my old boy; have you got your receipt ready?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: I was going to ſign it; but my eyes are ſo dim, I can't ſee with that curtain down.

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: As my wiſe's not here to complain of the light, I'll draw it up for you.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: That will do, I have light enough now.

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: And I have too much—Oh! the Jezabel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: Ruined!

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: My dear Mrs. Wilkins I beg ten thouſand pardons for letting ſo much light into the room, but I declare I cou'd not ſee to write my receipt.

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Johnſon! what brought you here; what have you to ſay for yourſelf; are you come to rob my houſe?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Oh! ho! I fear the dimneſs of my eyes have made others too clear ſighte—but, friend Wilkins, don't be too haſty in judging.

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: 'S'death and fire, man, ſhan't I believe my own eyes?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Not always.

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: You're dev'liſh conſiderate!

sp.speaker: Amb
sp.p: But we are all apt to be ſuſpicious at times—I'll wiſh you a good evening—there is my receipt: the fondeſt couples will ſpar now and then—but I never like to meddle in family quarrels.

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: Go, Madam; pack up your alls; and leave my houſe immediately; if you are in want of a morſel of bread, it wou'd give me pleaſure to refuſe it to you. As for you, Sir, I'll take care your buſineſs ſhall be done with Colonel Talbot—I'll ſee you both beggars, and that will be ſome ſatisfaction to me.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Colonel Talbot is coming up ſtairs, Sir, to ſpeak to you.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: Confuſion! I'm undone!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Johnſon, here!

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, Johnſon; your worthy gentleman is here on a viſit to that wretch my wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: Wretch, Mr. Wilkins!

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, an ungrateful wretch.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I'm ſorry, Johnſon—for this; I was given to underſtand you were come in ſearch of my ſon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: Wretch! I'll diſcover all, if I'm ruined for ever. (Aſide.) He's not your ſon, Sir—

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: Devil! Devil! what is ſhe going to ſay?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Not my ſon! ſpeak again, woman.

sp.speaker: Wilk.
sp.p: But dear Colonel, ſure you won't believe what this wicked woman will ſay?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Away, villain, and let me hear her—alarmed nature ſtarts up in my heart, and opens a thouſand ears to liſten to her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Wilk.
sp.p: He loſt your ſon, Sir, when he was a boy of twelve years old; and you may be ſure. Sir, it wasn't the kindeſt uſage made the child leave him; the booby he palmed upon you is his own.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Unprincipled, inhuman villain! let me hear the whole truth from your own lips, or by every power that's ſacred and divine, this moment is your laſt.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Dear Sir, put up your ſword, and I'll tell you every thing—What ſhe ſays is partly true; your ſon ſtrayed from me when he was about twelve years old; but had he been my own, I cou'dn't have uſed him better: as a proof of it, his mother, in her laſt illneſs, came, as ſhe often did, privately to ſee him, and was ſo well pleaſed with my wife's and my treatment of her ſon, that ſhe gave me a fifty-pound Bank note—I ſhall never forget the day; it was the laſt time I ever ſaw her: ſhe hung a ſmall picture of herſelf, ſet in gold, about the child's neck, and wept bitterly over him.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Can you produce that picture?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p:
Your ſon took it with him; he was ſo fond of it, I cou'd never keep it out of his hands but by locking it up; which I ſometimes did, as
the ſevereſt of all puniſhments I cou'd inflict upon him.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I muſt have better proof this tale is true, before I let you eſcape that juſtice I fear is due to your wickedneſs.—Johnſon, take him from my ſight, and let him be ſecur'd; I cannot bear to look at him.— Tell the company waiting for me in carriages at the door, to come in; for I am ſo agitated, and anxious for more particulars, I cannot quit this deteſted ſpot.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: They are here, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Crevelt, Mandeville, Charlotte, Harriet, Sir Oliver, Lady Oldſtock, and Count.

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: Dear Sir, what is the matter? Obſerving a confuſion in the houſe immediately after you went in, we were alarmed for your ſafety.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Oh, Crevelt! I am the unhappieſt of fathers; that creature whom you all ſuppoſe my ſon, is not ſo.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Good fortune be prais'd!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: He's ſon to the fellow who keeps this houſe—He ſays, my poor child ſtray'd from him when a boy; but this tale is ſo improbable, that I rather fear he has fall'n a victim to this fellow's villany and avarice.

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: Dear Sir, compoſe yourſelf, and hope human nature cannot be ſo deprav'd; it wrings my heart to ſee you in this diſtreſs—But who is this villain?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: His name is Wilkins.—When I committed my child to his care, he lived at Henly: he pretends he loſt him at twelve years old; and, oh! agony to think! if he, indeed, be living, he is at this moment a wandering outcaſt and a beggar.

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p:
Merciful heaven! What do I hear? Can
it be poſſible! Shall I, to my lov'd and honour'd patron, find a fond and living father? Sir, did that man loſe a ſon of yours at twelve years of age?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Yes, Crevelt; I have no ſon but you now.

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: I am your ſon, Sir—your happy ſon! that ſon you loſt.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You! You, Crevelt!

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, the veteran, whoſe name I bear, took me with him at the age you mention from Henly; where I lived with the man you have juſt named, whom I always thought my father; it was the pride of poor Crevelt's heart to have me believed his ſon: I bore his name, and publicly acknowledged him as my father; for you, Sir, could not have lov'd me better; his dying requeſt to me was, ſtill to retain the name of Crevelt, and never forget the man who made me a ſoldier.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My ſon! my ſon! The hand of Providence has ſurely directed every circumſtance of your life; you were brought to me a ſtranger and a child; I became your parent by reſiſtleſs inſtinct; in battle once I owed my life to you, and now a ſecond time you ſave it.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: O! Harriet. There is a chord of delight in my heart never touch'd before: and ſure, he who made that heart, now moves its ſprings to ecſtaſy by the finger of an angel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: He talk'd of your taking with you a picture of your mother—had you ever any ſuch thing?

sp.speaker: Crev.
sp.p: I have it ſtill, Sir, and ever wore it next my heart. (Producing the picture from his boſom.) You ſee the frame is ſhattered;—it was by a muſquet ball the day every body thought I was kill'd.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: It is indeed your mother; and ſee here thoſe ſpecks under the eye; are they my child's blood, or the tears of a fond parent?

sp.speaker: Johnſon
sp.p: You muſt not come in; I have already explained every thing ſufficiently.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: I tell you I will come in: zounds! will nobody father me?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Young man you have been deceived; you are Wilkins's ſon, not mine.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Pho, pho! Father, do you think I know no better?

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: If you don't come out this moment, and no longer diſturb my maſter, I'll take you by the ſhoulder.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Why here's a fellow for you—forgets he is talking to a captain!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That is a rank you are ſo utterly unfit for, that it would only expoſe you to unhappineſs and ridicule; therefore your commiſſion ſhall be ſold; and for being one day my ſon, the purchaſe money ſhall be appropriated to ſetting you up in buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: Well, what keeps you now?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: You are in a devil of a hurry, Mr. Johnſon: I find I muſt put up with old Jacob again; but let me aſk you one queſtion, an't I to be entitled to half-pay for my ſervices.

sp.speaker: Johnſ.
sp.p: You ſhall have full pay if you do'nt go about your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Well, if I can't be a half-pay captain I'll be a no-pay captain—for once a captain and always a captain.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Captain Crevelt—I beg your pardon, captain Talbot, give me your hand; you want nothing now but a wife, and if my daughter Charlotte—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Eh bien! Monſieur Chevalier, you have forgot?

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p:
Why, no, Count, I have not forgot; but you muſt know, whatever my reſpect for you may
be, there is not that man living whoſe alliance I ſo much deſire as colonel Talbot's; beſides, I underſtand there is another branch of the family of my mind.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Chevalier, I love and I reſpect the Engliſh, and by gar me vil have a wife among you.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.p: It is not in words to expreſs my pleaſure—to make a boſom friend, and find a near relation, in leſs time than others form a common acquaintance, overflows my heart with tranſport.

sp.speaker: Lady O.
sp.p: I could wiſh alſo to ſhew this affecting diſcovery touches me, if I was not apprehenſive, Sir Oliver, of your unfortunate ſuſpicious temper.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Captain Talbot, be ſo good as to ſtep this way—Do give my wife a kiſs; I know, my dear, your lips itch for it; and, with all her faults, believe me, ſhe has a heart that beats in uniſon to the feelings of all preſent, and a tear for miſery and friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Col. Tal.
sp.p: Miſs Oldſtock, it is your father's wiſh and mine to unite our families—now that I have a ſon I can propoſe to you, there is only your acceptance of him neceſſary to make me happy.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Why, Sir, if the gentleman has but courage to ſpeak for himſelf—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: As I don't expect the pleaſure of contradiction from either party on this occaſion, I'll join their hands, (Joining their hands.) without waiting for an anſwer—there—Colonel, you are now one of my family.

sp.speaker: Col. Tal.
sp.p: That aſſurance, Sir Oliver, ſeals, and completes my happineſs—you, Mandeville, ſhall ſhare a portion of my fortune as a ſon, and may happineſs ſtill wait on you and your lovely Harriot—and now (Addreſſing the audience.) if this court-martial, to whom we appeal, acquit us with honour, I ſhall bleſs the hour my boy ſaid, "He would be a Soldier."

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.byline: WRITTEN BY THE AUTHOR OF THE COMEDY, AND SPOKEN BY MRS. POPE.

lg.l: NOW critic Jove the ſcale aloft ſuſpends;
On whoſe dread beam the poet's fate depends:
Ye gods above, high arbiters of wit,
Who on your ſhilling thrones in council ſit;
You I implore, for our poor bard afraid,
To grant celeſtial, upper-gall'ry aid;
If you approve, with Cato I ſhall cry
The gods take care of poets in the ſky!
As for the ladies—they'll ſure hear my pray'r,
New charms good-nature lends the faireſt fair;
Beſides, I hardly think they can be foes,
To a fond maid who a brave ſoldier choſe.
Who like a ſoldier charms the fair one's eyes,
The queen of beauty was a ſoldier's prize?
In love as war, the brave man beſt ſucceeds,
Our ſex reveres that valour which it needs.
Ye beaux, ſo finely waiſted now-a-days,
That one wou'd almoſt ſwear you put on ſtays;
You, I confeſs, create no great alarm,
You hav'nt ſpirit to do good, or harm.
But yonder I eſpy ſome dangerous faces;
Good critics, I entreat your favouring graces:
All I requeſt is, when a fault's ſet down,
Its neighbouring beauty may be told the town;
But after this, if you attempt to growl,
I'll excommunicate you, every ſoul!
In my lawn ſleeves and ſhirt, I'll come ſo big,
In every thing a biſhop, but his wig:
Nay, if you doubt, an army I will bring
Of biſhops, who may crown the greateſt king:
Their ſleeves of lawn, the down-wings of the dove;
Their ſaſh, the ceſtus of the queen of love:
With aid like this, and aid you'll own divine,
Who wou'd not think ſucceſs were ſurely mine?
In anxious hope I wait the dread decree,
That muſt be final both to bard and me.
